title: Exodus Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Exodus chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Exodus Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Exodus Chapter 2.

questions.question: Who took a wife from the house of Levi?
options: A man of the house of Levi
A man of the house of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: A man of the house of Levi
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:1 states that a man of the house of Levi took to wife a daughter of Levi.

questions.question: How long did the mother hide her son after he was born?
questions.correctAnswer: Three months
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:2 explains that the woman hid her son for three months after he was born.

questions.question: What was the baby placed in when he could no longer be hidden?
questions.correctAnswer: An ark of bulrushes
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:3 describes how the mother placed the child in an ark of bulrushes and daubed it with slime and pitch.

questions.question: Who stood afar off to see what would happen to the child?
questions.correctAnswer: His sister
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:4 states that his sister stood afar off to see what would be done to him.

questions.question: Where did Pharaoh's daughter find the child?
options: Among the flags by the river's brink
questions.correctAnswer: Among the flags by the river's brink
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:5 tells that Pharaoh's daughter found the ark among the flags by the river's brink.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the child when Pharaoh's daughter opened the ark?
questions.correctAnswer: The babe wept
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:6 reports that when Pharaoh's daughter opened the ark, the babe wept.

questions.question: Who did the sister suggest Pharaoh's daughter call to nurse the child?
options: A nurse of the Hebrew women
questions.correctAnswer: A nurse of the Hebrew women
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:7 shows that the sister suggested calling a nurse of the Hebrew women to nurse the child.

questions.question: Who nursed the child after Pharaoh's daughter called her?
questions.correctAnswer: The child's mother
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:8-9 states that the maid called the child's mother, who then nursed the child.

questions.question: What name did Pharaoh's daughter give the child?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:10 says Pharaoh's daughter named the child Moses because she drew him out of the water.

questions.question: What did Moses do when he saw an Egyptian smiting a Hebrew?
questions.correctAnswer: He killed the Egyptian
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:11-12 tells that Moses slew the Egyptian who was smiting a Hebrew.

questions.question: True or False: Moses fled from Pharaoh and went to live in the land of Midian.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:15 confirms that Moses fled from Pharaoh and dwelt in the land of Midian.

questions.question: True or False: The priest of Midian had seven daughters who came to draw water.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:16 states that the priest of Midian had seven daughters who drew water.

questions.question: True or False: Moses helped the daughters of Midian by driving away the shepherds who were troubling them.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:17 records that Moses stood up and helped the daughters by watering their flock.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'And she bare him a son, and he called his name ______: for he said, I have been a stranger in a strange land.'
questions.correctAnswer: Gershom
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:22 shows that Moses named his son Gershom because he said, 'I have been a stranger in a strange land.'

questions.question: According to Exodus 2:24, what did God remember when He heard the groaning of the children of Israel?
options: His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
questions.correctAnswer: His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:24 states that God remembered His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob when He heard Israel's groaning.

medium.title: Exodus Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Exodus Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does the story of Moses' mother hiding him for three months teach us about faith and obedience in difficult circumstances?
options: She trusted God and obeyed His protection plan
She ignored the danger and hoped for the best
She gave Moses to strangers immediately
She left Moses unprotected by the river
questions.correctAnswer: She trusted God and obeyed His protection plan
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:2-3 shows Moses' mother carefully hiding him and then placing him in an ark, demonstrating her faith and obedience to protect him despite danger.

questions.question: A believer is facing fear about their family's safety. Based on Exodus 2, what practical biblical truth about trusting God in trials can you share?
options: God can provide protection through unexpected means
Fear should lead to abandoning faith
One must rely only on their own strength
Danger means God has abandoned us
questions.correctAnswer: God can provide protection through unexpected means
questions.explanation: Moses was hidden and then saved by Pharaoh's daughter (Exodus 2:3-6), showing God's providence even in difficult situations (Exodus 2:23-25).

questions.question: What biblical principle about serving others is illustrated by Moses helping Midian’s daughters at the well?
options: Serving others with kindness reflects God’s love
Helping only those you know is best
Avoid conflict by staying out of others’ affairs
questions.correctAnswer: Serving others with kindness reflects God’s love
questions.explanation: In Exodus 2:17, Moses helps the daughters despite opposition, illustrating practical service and love for neighbor.

questions.question: How does Moses’ action of defending the Hebrew slave teach us about standing against injustice with integrity?
options: It is righteous to defend those oppressed
One should only defend family members
questions.correctAnswer: It is righteous to defend those oppressed
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:11-12 highlights Moses’ intervention against unfair treatment, showing a commitment to justice and integrity.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and fear of consequences can we learn from Moses’ response when confronted by the Hebrew man?
options: Moses recognized his actions were known and feared consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Moses recognized his actions were known and feared consequences
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:14 shows Moses’ fear and acknowledgment of his actions, teaching humility and awareness of consequences.

questions.question: How does the story of Pharaoh seeking to kill Moses teach about perseverance through trials and trusting God’s timing?
options: Moses fled but God’s plan continued, showing perseverance
Moses gave up on God’s promise
questions.correctAnswer: Moses fled but God’s plan continued, showing perseverance
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:15-25 depicts Moses fleeing danger yet God’s covenant is remembered and His plan unfolds, teaching perseverance.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with loneliness in a new place. Based on Exodus 2, how can Moses’ experience encourage contentment and trust in God?
options: Moses was a stranger but found family and purpose with God’s help
Moses gave up and returned home immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Moses was a stranger but found family and purpose with God’s help
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:21-22 shows Moses marrying and naming his son ‘Gershom’, acknowledging being a stranger but finding hope and contentment.

questions.question: How does Pharaoh’s daughter’s willingness to pay Moses’ mother for nursing teach us about generosity and honoring family roles?
options: Generosity honors family and God’s design for parenting
Money should not be exchanged for care
Parents must abandon children for status
questions.correctAnswer: Generosity honors family and God’s design for parenting
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:8-9 shows Pharaoh’s daughter paying Moses’ mother to nurse him, honoring her role and demonstrating generosity.

questions.question: What does the naming of Moses teach us about God’s providence and the meaning we find in life’s events?
options: Names can reflect God’s deliverance and purpose
Names should only reflect family tradition
Names must be chosen by rulers alone
questions.correctAnswer: Names can reflect God’s deliverance and purpose
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:10 explains Moses’ name means ‘drawn out of the water’, reflecting God’s providence in his life.

questions.question: How does the children of Israel’s cry and God’s response teach us about prayer and God’s faithfulness to His promises?
options: God hears our cries and remembers His covenant
Prayer has no impact on God
Promises are made without intent to keep
questions.correctAnswer: God hears our cries and remembers His covenant
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:23-25 shows Israel’s cries reaching God, who remembers His covenant, teaching faith in God’s faithfulness through prayer.

questions.question: True or False: Moses was raised by his biological mother from birth and never left her care.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:3-10 shows Moses was hidden by his mother but later raised by Pharaoh’s daughter after she took him from the river.

questions.question: True or False: Moses helped the Midianite women despite opposition from other shepherds, showing courage and kindness.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:16-17 records Moses defending and helping the daughters despite the shepherds’ hostility, exemplifying courage and kindness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Moses named his son Gershom because he said, "I have been a _____ in a strange land."
questions.correctAnswer: stranger
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:22 explains Moses named his son Gershom meaning 'stranger', expressing his experience living as a foreigner.

questions.question: How does Moses’ flight to Midian demonstrate the importance of trusting God’s guidance when facing consequences for righteous actions?
options: Moses fled but God’s plan led him to a new purpose
Running away shows lack of faith
questions.correctAnswer: Moses fled but God’s plan led him to a new purpose
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:15-21 shows Moses fleeing danger yet God providing new opportunities, teaching trust in God’s direction amid trials.

questions.question: What does Exodus 2 teach about the role of godly parents in protecting and nurturing children even under threat?
options: Parents must act with faith and wisdom to protect their children
Children should be abandoned if threatened
questions.correctAnswer: Parents must act with faith and wisdom to protect their children
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:1-3 emphasizes the mother’s faith and wise actions to protect Moses, modeling godly parenting under threat.

hard.title: Exodus Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Exodus Chapter 2.

questions.question: What is the significance of the name 'Moses' as given by Pharaoh's daughter, and how does it relate to typology in Scripture?
options: It means 'drawn out,' symbolizing deliverance from water, foreshadowing salvation (Exodus 2:10)
It means 'leader,' indicating Moses’ future role as a judge
It means 'servant,' reflecting his humble beginnings
questions.correctAnswer: It means 'drawn out,' symbolizing deliverance from water, foreshadowing salvation (Exodus 2:10)
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:10 states that Moses' name means 'Because I drew him out of the water,' which foreshadows the salvation theme central to his mission and parallels baptism imagery in the New Testament.

questions.question: How does the ark of bulrushes in Exodus 2:3 serve as a literary and typological device within the biblical narrative?
options: It prefigures Noah's ark as a symbol of deliverance from judgment
It represents the tabernacle as God’s dwelling place
It parallels the basket in Daniel’s story, symbolizing preservation
It foreshadows the protective role of the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures Noah's ark as a symbol of deliverance from judgment
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:3 describes the ark of bulrushes used to save Moses, symbolically prefiguring Noah’s ark which also delivers God’s people from destruction, highlighting a recurring theme of divine rescue.

questions.question: Which cultural practice is reflected in Pharaoh's daughter's decision to employ a Hebrew nurse for Moses, and what does this imply about Israelite-Egyptian relations?
options: Respect for native customs and acknowledgment of Hebrew identity (Exodus 2:7-9)
Assimilation policy of Egyptians to absorb Hebrews
Egyptian distrust of Hebrews, keeping them under surveillance
Pharaoh's secret support for the Hebrew people
questions.correctAnswer: Respect for native customs and acknowledgment of Hebrew identity (Exodus 2:7-9)
questions.explanation: The request to call a Hebrew nurse (Exodus 2:7) shows Pharaoh's daughter’s recognition of Hebrew customs and implies a nuanced relationship, contrasting the broader oppression.

questions.question: What is the historical significance of Moses fleeing to Midian, and how does this reflect Ancient Near Eastern customs?
options: Exile to a foreign land to avoid execution was common (Exodus 2:15)
It represents a pilgrimage to a holy site
It is a symbolic death and rebirth motif
It reflects a political alliance through marriage
questions.correctAnswer: Exile to a foreign land to avoid execution was common (Exodus 2:15)
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:15 shows Moses fleeing to Midian, reflecting the common ANE practice where fugitives sought asylum in foreign lands to escape death sentences.

questions.question: How does the narrative structure around Moses’ killing of the Egyptian and subsequent flight demonstrate a chiastic pattern?
options: Moses acts as deliverer (kill Egyptian), then becomes an exile (flight) (Exodus 2:11-15)
The story is told in a circular manner
questions.correctAnswer: Moses acts as deliverer (kill Egyptian), then becomes an exile (flight) (Exodus 2:11-15)
questions.explanation: Verses 11-15 show a chiastic pattern: Moses first delivers an oppressed Hebrew by killing an Egyptian (A), then becomes a fugitive in Midian (B), illustrating the reversal and complexity of his role.

questions.question: What is the theological implication of God remembering His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob in Exodus 2:24?
options: God’s faithfulness ensures deliverance despite Israel’s suffering
God is indifferent to human suffering
The covenant is conditional on Israel’s obedience
God’s covenant is limited to the patriarchs only
questions.correctAnswer: God’s faithfulness ensures deliverance despite Israel’s suffering
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:24 emphasizes God’s remembrance of the covenant, assuring that despite Israel’s bondage, God's promises will bring redemption.

questions.question: How does the motif of water function symbolically in the events of Exodus 2, especially in relation to Moses’ birth and rescue?
options: Water represents both danger and salvation (Exodus 2:3, 10)
Water is a sign of purification exclusively
Water is depicted as a barrier between peoples
questions.correctAnswer: Water represents both danger and salvation (Exodus 2:3, 10)
questions.explanation: The Nile waters threaten Moses' life, yet also serve as the means of his rescue and naming (Exodus 2:3, 10), showing water’s dual symbolic role.

questions.question: What is the significance of Moses’ marriage to Zipporah, daughter of the priest of Midian, in the context of intercultural relations?
options: It represents integration and alliance between Hebrews and Midianites (Exodus 2:21)
It marks Moses’ rejection of Hebrew identity
It is a political strategy to gain Egyptian favor
It symbolizes Israel’s future conquest of Midian
questions.correctAnswer: It represents integration and alliance between Hebrews and Midianites (Exodus 2:21)
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:21 shows Moses marrying into Midian, indicating cultural integration and foreshadowing God's use of foreign lands in His plans.

questions.question: True or False: Moses’ act of killing the Egyptian was carried out openly without concern for witnesses.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:12 shows Moses looked this way and that, ensuring no man was present before he killed the Egyptian, indicating secrecy.

questions.question: Which literary device is employed when Moses’ sister watches 'afar off' to see what will happen to him (Exodus 2:4)?
questions.correctAnswer: Foreshadowing
questions.explanation: The sister’s watchful stance (Exodus 2:4) foreshadows later protective actions and Moses’ preservation, enhancing narrative suspense.

questions.question: How does the social status of Pharaoh’s daughter impact the narrative’s portrayal of divine providence?
options: Her royal status facilitates Moses’ survival, showing God’s use of political authority (Exodus 2:5-10)
Her status leads to Moses’ rejection by the Hebrews
She is portrayed negatively for defying Pharaoh’s orders
Her actions have no theological significance
questions.correctAnswer: Her royal status facilitates Moses’ survival, showing God’s use of political authority (Exodus 2:5-10)
questions.explanation: Pharaoh’s daughter’s position enables her to save Moses (Exodus 2:5-10), illustrating God’s providential use of unexpected agents.

questions.question: What cultural or legal norms might explain Pharaoh’s intent to kill Moses after the murder incident?
options: Egyptian laws forbade rebellion and killing of Egyptians by slaves or foreigners (Exodus 2:15)
Pharaoh was personally offended by Moses
Moses was accused of treason against the throne
It was a ritual purification requirement
questions.correctAnswer: Egyptian laws forbade rebellion and killing of Egyptians by slaves or foreigners (Exodus 2:15)
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:15 shows Pharaoh sought to kill Moses, reflecting strict Egyptian laws against such acts to maintain social order.

questions.question: How do the cries of the Israelites in bondage and God’s response in Exodus 2:23-25 contribute to the overarching theme of redemption in the Pentateuch?
options: They establish God’s active role in history responding to suffering
They show God’s indifference to human plight
They emphasize human effort over divine intervention
They reveal God’s judgment without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: They establish God’s active role in history responding to suffering
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:23-25 highlights God hearing Israel’s cries and remembering His covenant, reinforcing the theme of divine redemption.

questions.question: What is the significance of the name Gershom given to Moses’ son, and how does it reflect Moses’ experience?
options: It means 'a stranger there,' reflecting Moses’ alienation in Midian (Exodus 2:22)
It means 'leader of many,' symbolizing future Israelite leadership
It means 'gift of God,' indicating divine blessing
questions.correctAnswer: It means 'a stranger there,' reflecting Moses’ alienation in Midian (Exodus 2:22)
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:22 explains Gershom means 'I have been a stranger in a strange land,' directly reflecting Moses’ status.

questions.question: How does Moses’ intervention in the quarrel between two Hebrews (Exodus 2:13-14) illustrate themes of justice and leadership?
options: Moses asserts authority and attempts to mediate, foreshadowing judicial role (Exodus 2:13-14)
He avoids involvement in community disputes
He sides with the stronger party
questions.correctAnswer: Moses asserts authority and attempts to mediate, foreshadowing judicial role (Exodus 2:13-14)
questions.explanation: Moses’ confrontation in Exodus 2:13-14 shows early leadership qualities and concern for justice among his people.

theological.title: Exodus Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Exodus Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the significance of Moses being hidden for three months by his mother?
options: To protect him from Pharaoh's decree to kill Hebrew male infants
To hide him because he was a weak child
To prepare him for priestly duties
To prevent him from being adopted by Egyptians
questions.correctAnswer: To protect him from Pharaoh's decree to kill Hebrew male infants
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:2 shows Moses' mother hid him to protect him from Pharaoh's command to kill Hebrew boys. This act foreshadows God's providential protection over His deliverer, consistent with God's protection of Isaac (Genesis 21:20-21), Samuel (1 Samuel 1:11-20), and Jesus (Matthew 2:13-15).

questions.question: What materials were used to make the ark in which Moses was placed?
questions.correctAnswer: Bulrushes, slime, and pitch
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:3 describes the ark made of bulrushes daubed with slime and pitch, showing human ingenuity under divine providence. This preservation method echoes God's care in Noah's Ark (Genesis 6:14), symbolizing salvation and deliverance.

questions.question: Who witnessed Moses being placed in the ark and stayed nearby to see what would happen?
questions.correctAnswer: His sister
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:4 mentions Moses' sister standing afar off to see his fate, indicating early faith and protection within his family. This parallels the faith of Anna who watched over Jesus (Luke 2:36-38) and the vigilance of faithful witnesses in Scripture.

questions.question: What prompted Pharaoh's daughter to take the Hebrew child from the river?
options: She had compassion when she saw the child weeping
She wanted a servant for her household
She recognized him as a prince of Egypt
She was searching for a lost Egyptian child
questions.correctAnswer: She had compassion when she saw the child weeping
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:6 shows Pharaoh's daughter's compassion upon seeing the crying child, demonstrating God's mercy working through an unlikely agent. This reflects divine compassion in salvation history (Psalm 78:38, Luke 1:78).

questions.question: Who was called to nurse the baby Moses after he was found by Pharaoh's daughter?
questions.correctAnswer: His own mother
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:7-9 reveals that Moses' sister arranged for their mother to nurse him, illustrating God's providential care and the preservation of Hebrew identity. This arrangement also prefigures God's use of family and covenant community in salvation (Isaiah 49:15).

questions.question: What name was given to the child and what is the meaning of this name?
options: Moses, meaning 'drawn out of the water'
questions.correctAnswer: Moses, meaning 'drawn out of the water'
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:10 states Pharaoh's daughter named him Moses because she drew him out of the water. This name signifies deliverance, prefiguring Christ as the one who rescues from death (John 3:14-15, Hebrews 11:23).

questions.question: What motivated Moses to kill the Egyptian who was beating a Hebrew?
options: He identified with his Hebrew brethren and sought justice
He wanted to become ruler of Egypt
He was angry at Pharaoh's daughter
He was acting out of personal revenge
questions.correctAnswer: He identified with his Hebrew brethren and sought justice
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:11-12 shows Moses' empathy with his people and his sense of justice, reflecting God's concern for the oppressed (Psalm 82:3-4, Isaiah 1:17). This act reveals human sinfulness and the need for divine salvation.

questions.question: Why did Moses flee to the land of Midian?
options: Pharaoh sought to kill him after he killed the Egyptian
He wanted to study under Midianite priests
He was exiled by the Hebrews
He was called by God to Midian
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh sought to kill him after he killed the Egyptian
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:15 records Moses fleeing because Pharaoh sought to kill him, illustrating the consequences of sin and God's providential protection. This exile parallels Joseph's time in Egypt (Genesis 39:7-20) and Jesus' flight to Egypt (Matthew 2:13).

questions.question: How did Moses first assist the daughters of the priest of Midian?
options: By defending them from shepherds and watering their flock
By giving them food and shelter
By leading them to a city
questions.correctAnswer: By defending them from shepherds and watering their flock
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:17 describes Moses helping the daughters by defending them and watering the flock, demonstrating his compassionate character and foreshadowing his role as a shepherd of Israel (John 10:11).

questions.question: What was the name of Moses' wife and what does her name signify in relation to Moses' life?
options: Zipporah, signifying a connection to Midian
questions.correctAnswer: Zipporah, signifying a connection to Midian
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:21 identifies Zipporah as Moses' wife, marking his integration into Midianite society. This union reflects God's providential preparation of Moses for his mission (Genesis 24:67, Judges 4:4).

questions.question: What is the meaning of the name Moses gave to his son Gershom?
options: 'I have been a stranger in a strange land'
questions.correctAnswer: 'I have been a stranger in a strange land'
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:22 shows Gershom means 'stranger in a strange land,' reflecting Moses' experience of alienation and foreshadowing the Israelites' sojourn in Egypt (Hebrews 11:13).

questions.question: What happened in Israel after the death of the king of Egypt according to this chapter?
options: The children of Israel sighed because of bondage and cried to God
Pharaoh released the Israelites from slavery
questions.correctAnswer: The children of Israel sighed because of bondage and cried to God
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:23 describes Israel's suffering and their prayers reaching God, showing God's attentiveness to the oppressed and His covenant faithfulness (Psalm 34:17, Isaiah 63:9).

questions.question: How did God respond to the cries of the Israelites in bondage?
options: God heard their groaning and remembered His covenant with the patriarchs
questions.correctAnswer: God heard their groaning and remembered His covenant with the patriarchs
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:24 shows God's covenant faithfulness and compassion, a foundational theme throughout Scripture (Deuteronomy 7:9, Psalm 105:8, Romans 11:29).

questions.question: What does God's looking upon the children of Israel and having respect for them signify theologically?
options: God's mercy and readiness to act for His covenant people
questions.correctAnswer: God's mercy and readiness to act for His covenant people
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:25 indicates God's compassionate regard and willingness to intervene, reflecting His steadfast love (Exodus 34:6-7, Lamentations 3:22-23, Luke 1:78-79).

questions.question: How does Moses' killing of the Egyptian relate to the biblical doctrine of sin and justice?
options: It reveals human sinfulness and God's call for justice
It shows that ends justify means
It is an example of divine approval of murder
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals human sinfulness and God's call for justice
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:12-14 illustrates both the reality of human sin and the need for righteous justice. Scripture consistently condemns murder (Exodus 20:13) but calls for justice for the oppressed (Isaiah 1:17, Romans 12:19).

questions.question: What theological theme is reflected by Moses being drawn out of water and later becoming Israel's deliverer?
options: Salvation and deliverance through God's providence
The rejection of Israel by God
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation and deliverance through God's providence
questions.explanation: Exodus 2:10 portrays Moses' rescue from water as a symbol of salvation, prefiguring baptism (1 Corinthians 10:2) and Christ's deliverance (John 3:5), emphasizing God's sovereign salvation plan.
